page.title: 08Local Customs
page.content: The Pace Egg - or "Pasch" Egg as it used to be known dates back to the Middle Ages, when mummers would collect eggs as payment for their performance. The "Pasch" or peace eggs were brightly-coloured and held to be symbolic of Christ's resurrection at Easter. In the present day, local amateur dramatic groups still try to keep alive the essentials of the performance of the old-time mummers, who, in one of the most ancient forms of drama, mimed a primitive pagan rite of the renewal of life, as winter gave way to spring. From the Middle Ages onwards, the heroes are St George and the other patron saints; the villains are the Turkish, or other East Mediterranean, enemies in the period
